statement:
Let $\mathbb{F}_q$ be the finite field of $q$ elements with
characteristic $p$. Let $f_i(x_1,\ldots, x_n)$, $i=1,2,\ldots, r$, be
polynomial of $n$ variables over $\mathbb{F}_q$. If $n >
\sum_{i=1}^r \deg(f_i)$, then the number of solutions over
$\mathbb{F}_q$ to the system of equations $$\begin{aligned}
f_1(x_1,x_2,\ldots, x_n) &=0\\
f_2(x_1,x_2,\ldots, x_n) &=0\\
\vdots & \\
f_r(x_1,x_2,\ldots, x_n) &=0\end{aligned}$$ is divisible by $p$. In
particular, if none of the polynomials $f_1$, $f_2,\ldots, f_r$ have
constant term, then there are at least $p$ solutions.
